p.text: [heading insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[64], effective 1 January 2009]
See Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 10 of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,225] s 135 General discretion to exclude evidence

p.text: The court may refuse to admit evidence if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger that the evidence might:
be unfairly prejudicial to a party, or
be misleading or confusing, or
cause or result in undue waste of time.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 640–644
ALRC 38 para 122(b)
The term “probative value” is defined in the Dictionary.
Legislation cited in [51,225.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 135, ss 55, 56.

The provisions of s 135 create a wider discretion than that provided at common law. In particular the discretion in civil proceedings to exclude evidence if its probative value is substantially outweighed by, inter alia, its prejudicial effect is generally inconsistent with the common law: see David Syme & Co Ltd v Mather [1977] VR 516 ; Polycarpou v Australian Wire Industries Pty Ltd (1995) 36 NSWLR 49 ; cf Taylor v Harvey [1986] 2 Qd R 137. The creation of the discretion in connection with civil proceedings is a corollary of the other changes made by the Act to the concepts of relevance and admissibility — see, in particular, ss 55 and 56 of the Act. The inability to test hearsay evidence by cross-examination may, depending on the nature of the evidence and its relevance to the proceedings, give rise to unfair prejudice sufficient to warrant its exclusion: Bakerland Pty Ltd v Coleridge (2002) 12 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61–521; [2002] NSWCA 30; BC200201115 at [55] ; Roach v Page (No 11) [2003] NSWSC 907; BC200305938 .
Legislation cited in [51,225.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 135(a), s 135(b), ss 65, 66.

It is only unfair prejudice that will enliven the operation of s 135(a) : R v Cakovski [2002] NSWSC 608; BC200203912 ; Roach v Page (No 11) [2003] NSWSC 907; BC200305938 . The mere fact that the proffered evidence is adverse, and thus prejudicial, to a party does not mean that its admission is “unfair”. A finding of "unfair" prejudice generally requires a conclusion that the admission may result in procedural or substantive unfairness.

Procedural unfairness may arise if the author of a particular document is unavailable for cross-examination: see Young v Coupe [2004] NSWSC 546; BC200403825 and the authorities cited therein. It may also arise in circumstances where a particular document is not produced in response to a subpoena, but is then produced by a witness in the course of giving evidence: Dyldam Developments Pty Ltd v Jones [2008] NSWCA 56; BC200802355 esp at [42]–[52]. Several judicial statements emphasise the fact that since other provisions of the Act conditionally permit hearsay evidence, there are inherent limitations in characterising the mere unavailability of cross-examination as itself sufficient to warrant a conclusion of procedural unfairness: see Commonwealth v McLean (1996) 41 NSWLR 389 at 400–2; BC9606432 (unfair where effective cross-examination unavailable); Papakosmas v R (1999) 196 CLR 297; 164 ALR 548; [1999] HCA 37; BC9904591 at [93] (the admissibility criteria in ss 65 and 66 necessarily contemplate the possibility of no cross-examination); Ordukaya v Hicks [2000] NSWCA 180; BC200003956 at [6], [35]–[40] (absence in cross-examination does not require a conclusion of unfair prejudice); R v Clark (2001) 123 A Crim R 506; [2001] NSWCCA 494; BC200107874 at [164] (procedural prejudice must be significant before it could be characterised as unfair); Bakerland Pty Ltd v Coleridge (2002) 12 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61–521; [2002] NSWCA 30; BC200201115 at [55] (unavailability of material cross-examination may give rise to unfair prejudice); R v Suteski (2002) 56 NSWLR 182; 137 A Crim R 371; [2002] NSWCCA 509; BC200208042 at [126]–[127] (absence of cross-examination not decisive). However, it is also true to point out that the “unfairly prejudicial” criterion is a disjunctive exclusionary ground. It is presumably intended to permit a conclusion that evidence should be excluded even if the court is not affirmatively satisfied that the evidence is (or might be) misleading or confusing (see s 135(b) of the Evidence Act 1995). The clearly disjunctive nature of the criteria certainly encourages the conclusion that issues of procedural unfairness are relevant to the assessment of whether or not “probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger” of unfair prejudice.
Substantive unfairness is closely related to the criteria of “misleading” or “confusing” evidence to which s 135(a) of the Evidence Act 1995 applies.

level.toc-caption: [51,225.25] Unfairly prejudicial, misleading and confusing evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [51,225.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 135(b).

heading.title: Unfairly prejudicial, misleading and confusing evidence

p.text: In its report which led to the enactment of the uniform evidence law, the Australian Law Reform Commission explained that s 135(b) might apply where there was some danger that a court might incorrectly assess the weight of a particular piece of evidence. It has since been observed, more specifically, that the section might apply if the evidence is sought to be adduced in a form which is inadequate and incomplete and might be misleading and confusing: Hughes Aircraft Systems International v Airservices Australia (No 3) (1997) 80 FCR 276; (1998) ATPR ¶41–612; BC9707410 ; or logically unconnected with the issues in the case: R v McNeill (Ruling No 2) [2007] NFSC 3; BC200703677 at [44] ; Ainsworth v Burden [2005] NSWCA 174; BC200504199 at [99] ; R v Lockyer (1996) 89 A Crim R 457; BC9604931 ; Ordukaya v Hicks [2000] NSWCA 180; BC200003956 ; Vitali v Stachnik [2001] NSWSC 303; BC200101803 ; Assaf v Skalkos [1999] NSWSC 1329; BC9909145 ; Boardman v DPP [1975] AC 421 at 456; [1974] 3 All ER 887 ; Duke v R (1979) 22 SASR 46 at 47–8; 1 A Crim R 39 ; Scott v R [1989] AC 1242 at 1258–9; [1989] 2 All ER 305 ; Masters v R (1992) 26 NSWLR 450 at 479; 59 A Crim R 445 ; Pfennig v R (1995) 182 CLR 461 at 487–8, 528; 127 ALR 99; [1995] HCA 7; BC9506435 ; R v BD (1997) 94 A Crim R 131 at 139; BC9703233 ; Papakosmas v R (1999) 196 CLR 297; 164 ALR 548; [1999] HCA 37; BC9904591 at [29], [91], [98] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,230] s 136 General discretion to limit use of evidence

leg:heading.title: General discretion to limit use of evidence

p.text: The court may limit the use to be made of evidence if there is a danger that a particular use of the evidence might:
be unfairly prejudicial to a party, or
be misleading or confusing.

level.toc-caption: [51,230.5] Limiting the purpose of admissible evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [51,230.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 60, 77, s 78, s 95(1).

heading.title: Limiting the purpose of admissible evidence

p.text: The question whether admissible evidence is evidence for all purposes has been the subject of debate in the authorities: see [29.2.25] . In the Evidence Act itself there are some express declarations that evidence that is admissible for one purpose may be used for other purposes: see ss 60 and 77 in relation to the hearsay rule and the opinion rule. In other instances there are express declarations that evidence is only admissible for a specific purpose: see s 95(1) in relation to tendency and coincidence evidence. The present section permits the court to control the use to which admissible evidence may be put. That potential control must be exercised in a way that does not subvert the underlying policy of the legislation: Papakosmas v R (1999) 196 CLR 297; 164 ALR 548; [1999] HCA 37; BC9904591 . The criterion for the discretionary exclusion is the risk of prejudice or misapprehension, rather than satisfaction of its likely occurrence: Seven Network Ltd v News Ltd (No 8) (2005) 224 ALR 317; [2005] FCA 1348; BC200507117 at [16] . No particular factor is a conclusive indicator of the relevant risk. But one potentially significant consideration is the prospect that the evidence cannot be effectively tested by cross-examination: Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2001] NSWSC 222; BC200101315 at [46] ; Bakerland Pty Ltd v Coleridge [2002] NSWCA 30; BC200201115 at [55] ; Roach v Page (No 11) [2003] NSWSC 907; BC200305938 at [19] ; Ringrow Pty Ltd v BP Australian Ltd (2003) 130 FCR 569; [2003] FCA 933; BC200305022 ; Seven Network Ltd v News Ltd (No 8) (2005) 224 ALR 317; [2005] FCA 1348; BC200507117 at [13], [24] (opinion evidence — admissible on basis other than conformity with Evidence Act 1995 s 78 ). In multiparty proceedings the mere fact that evidence is admissible against only some of the parties does not necessarily require a formal limitation on its admission in the proceedings: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Vines (2003) 48 ACSR 282; [2003] NSWSC 995; BC200306528 ; Sylvia v Cmr of Taxation [2001] NSWSC 562; BC200103677 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,235] s 137 Exclusion of prejudicial evidence in criminal proceedings

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of prejudicial evidence in criminal proceedings

p.text: In a criminal proceeding, the court must refuse to admit evidence adduced by the prosecutor if its probative value is outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 957
Legislation cited in [51,235.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 137.

At common law a trial judge in criminal proceedings has a discretion to exclude evidence if its probative value is outweighed by the risk of unfair prejudice from its admission: R v Edelsten (1990) 21 NSWLR 542 at 551–6 ; Noor Mohamed v R [1949] AC 182 at 192 ; Driscoll v R (1977) 137 CLR 517 at 517; 15 ALR 47; BC7700059 . The application of s 137 does not involve the exercise of a discretion but requires the defendant to discharge the onus of establishing the matters referred to in the section: Gilmour v Environmental Protection Authority; Tableland Top Dressing v Environmental Protection Authority (2002) 55 NSWLR 593; 134 A Crim R 466; [2002] NSWCCA 399; BC200205743 at [46]. The section requires a trial judge to assess the probative value of the evidence in question, assess the danger of unfair prejudice and then to weigh the former against the latter. If the conclusion is reached that there is a real risk of unfair prejudice, the provisions of s 137 render it mandatory to exclude the evidence: see R v Blick (2000) 111 A Crim R 326; [2000] NSWCCA 61; BC200000946 ; R v SJRC [2007] NSWCCA 142; BC200703797 . In assessing the probative value, the issue for a judge is the rational capacity of the evidence, if accepted, to affect the assessment of probability. That issue does not involve consideration of the reliability and credibility of witnesses — unless they are so significant that they entirely deprive the evidence of probative value: see R v Shamouil (2006) 66 NSWLR 228; [2006] NSWCCA 112; BC200602242 at [60]–[64] , cited with approval in Irani v R [2008] NSWCCA 217; BC200808212 at [25] .

The mere fact that disputed evidence is contrary to the opposing parties case does not constitute “unfair prejudice”, nor is there “unfair prejudice” merely because the nature or complexity of the evidence means there is a possibility it might be misunderstood or given undue significance: R v Lisoff BC9907637; [1999] NSWCCA 364 (expert DNA evidence wrongly rejected in jury trial).

Although a ruling under s 137 is not properly characterised as the exercise of a discretion, it nevertheless involves an impressionistic assessment and, for the purposes of any appeal, can only be reviewed in accordance with the principles set out in House v R (1936) 55 CLR 499 at 504–5; 10 ALJR 202 : see Can v R [2007] NSWCCA 176; BC200705311 . see also [SCA s 75A.35] , [SCA s 75A.40] , [SCA s 101.70] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,240] s 138 Exclusion of improperly or illegally obtained evidence

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of improperly or illegally obtained evidence

p.text: Evidence that was obtained:
improperly or in contravention of an Australian law, or
in consequence of an impropriety or of a contravention of an Australian law,
is not to be admitted unless the desirability of admitting the evidence outweighs the undesirability of admitting evidence that has been obtained in the way in which the evidence was obtained.

Without limiting subsection (1) , evidence of an admission that was made during or in consequence of questioning, and evidence obtained in consequence of the admission, is taken to have been obtained improperly if the person conducting the questioning:

did, or omitted to do, an act in the course of the questioning even though he or she knew or ought reasonably to have known that the act or omission was likely to impair substantially the ability of the person being questioned to respond rationally to the questioning, or

made a false statement in the course of the questioning even though he or she knew or ought reasonably to have known that the statement was false and that making the false statement was likely to cause the person who was being questioned to make an admission.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account under subsection (1) , it is to take into account:
the probative value of the evidence, and
the importance of the evidence in the proceeding, and
the nature of the relevant offence, cause of action or defence and the nature of the subject-matter of the proceeding, and
the gravity of the impropriety or contravention, and
whether the impropriety or contravention was deliberate or reckless, and
whether the impropriety or contravention was contrary to or inconsistent with a right of a person recognised by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and
whether any other proceeding (whether or not in a court) has been or is likely to be taken in relation to the impropriety or contravention, and
the difficulty (if any) of obtaining the evidence without impropriety or contravention of an Australian law.
The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights is set out in Schedule 2 to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 of the Commonwealth.
[s 138 am Act 54 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 2]
ALRC 38 para 164(a)
Legislation cited in [51,240.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

The provisions of s 138 are generally consistent with the common law as laid down by the High Court in Bunning v Cross (1978) 141 CLR 54; 19 ALR 641; 52 ALJR 561; BC7800046 (admissibility of breath analysis). However, there are four significant differences. First, in certain circumstances, the present section could permit the admission of evidence despite an express provision in other legislation declaring it inadmissible: Violi v Berrivale Orchards Ltd (2000) 99 FCR 580; 173 ALR 518; [2000] FCA 797; BC200003225 (evidence admitted in Federal Court proceedings despite contravention of the NSW Listening Devices Act 1984). Second, under the section the party tendering the evidence bears the onus, once impropriety has been shown, of justifying the admission. The third difference is that the criteria a court is entitled to take into account under s 138(3) are generally wider than those matters considered by Stephen and Aickin JJ in Bunning v Cross, above, at 78–81.The fourth difference is that the present section also applies to civil proceedings.

The section is concerned with the manner in which the witness who is to give the particular evidence came to be in possession of it: see Taylor v Burgess (2002) 29 Fam LR 167; (2002) FLC 93-120; [2002] NSWSC 676; BC200204233 . In this context, the word "obtained" is to be given its normal everyday meaning and is not to be artificially restricted: DPP v Coe [2003] NSWSC 363; BC200302005 ; cf DPP v Carr (2002) 127 A Crim R 151; [2002] NSWSC 194; BC200201026 ; see also Robinett v Police (2000) 78 SASR 85; 116 A Crim R 492; [2000] SASC 405; BC200007369 .

The exercise of the discretionary power conferred by the section involves two steps. The first is to determine whether evidence sought to be adduced was, in fact, obtained improperly or unlawfully in one of the senses identified in s 138(1)(a) and 138(1)(b) . The burden of satisfying that condition lies on the party seeking to have the evidence excluded: Parker v Comptroller General of Customs (2009) 252 ALR 619; [2009] HCA 7; BC200900445 at [28] .

For the purposes of s 138(1)(a) , 138(1)(b) , the core meaning of “contravention” involves either doing what is legally forbidden, or failing to do what is required by law – whether the legal obligation is statutory or non-statutory. A mere failure to satisfy a pre-condition for the effective exercise of a (statutory) power is neither a relevant “contravention” nor an “impropriety”: Parker v Comptroller General of Customs , above, at [29]–[30].

In the absence of a relevant contravention of Australian law, there is an uncertain scope for the exclusion of evidence that was obtained by impropriety. The kinds of impropriety often relied on include confessional statements and evidence of provocation: Ridgeway v R (1995) 184 CLR 19; 129 ALR 41; BC9506420 ; Robinson v Woolworths Ltd (2005) 64 NSWLR 612; 227 ALR 353; [2005] NSWCCA 426; BC200511151 at [16]–[38] . It may also include situations where evidence is obtained by deception: Parker v Comptroller-General of Customs (2007) 243 ALR 574; [2007] NSWCA 348; BC200710596 at [56] . But these are illustrative, rather than exclusive examples. Whether there has been a relevant impropriety depends on consideration of a number of issues. They include identification of the minimum standards which should be regarded as applicable to a particular set of circumstances, and the degree of departure from those standards: Robinson v Woolworths Ltd , above, at [22], [23] (whether the departure reflects "marginal" non-compliance, or alternatively inconsistency, with the standards). In this context it has been held that minimum standards require a body such as ASIC, in the exercise of its wide powers of discovery, to ensure that it acts within the terms of any protocols with which it has agreed to comply: ASIC v McDonald (No 5) [2008] NSWSC 1169; BC200809713 at [18]–[25] .

The second step is to consider whether, despite that conclusion, the discretionary considerations favour the admission of the evidence. The party seeking admission of the evidence has the burden of proof of facts relevant to matters weighing in favour of admission. It also has the burden of persuading the court that the desirability of admitting the evidence outweighs the undesirability of admitting evidence obtained in the way it was obtained: Parker v Comptroller General of Customs (2009) 252 ALR 619; [2009] HCA 7; BC200900445 . The considerations listed in s 138(3) include factors such as the probative value of the evidence, the gravity and/or deliberation with which the illegality or impropriety was committed, whether the evidence could have been obtained without resort to such impropriety or illegality, fairness and public policy considerations will all be relevant: Foster v R (1993) 113 ALR 1; 67 ALJR 550; BC9303566 ; R v Dungay (2001) 126 A Crim R 216; [2001] NSWCCA 443; BC200106791 ; see also R v Swaffield (1998) 192 CLR 159; 151 ALR 98; [1998] HCA 1; BC9800011 . The matters listed in s 138(3) are mandatory, but not exclusive considerations: Parker v Comptroller General of Customs , above, at [57]–[65].

It is not necessary, for the purposes of the exercise of the discretion, to mechanically go through each of the provisions in s 138(3): R v Salem (1997) 96 A Crim R 421; BC9705021 . The proper approach is to simply have regard to such of those matters in s 138(3) as might be applicable, and then strike the balance contemplated by s 138(1): R v Burrell [2001] NSWSC 120; BC200100725 . Necessarily that "balance" will depend on an impressionistic and subjective evaluation of the particular circumstances of the case. However, what can be said without equivocation is that obtaining evidence in deliberate, wilful or even reckless disregard of an individual's civil rights is likely to be a strong factor against the exercise of the discretion to admit the evidence: Parker v Comptroller-General of Customs (2009) 252 ALR 619; [2009] HCA 7; BC200900445 at [63]–[65] (improper issue of search warrant — impropriety not deliberate — evidence properly admitted).
For the purposes of section 138(1)(a) , evidence of a statement made or an act done by a person during questioning is taken to have been obtained improperly if:
the person was under arrest for an offence at the time, and
the questioning was conducted by an investigating official who was at the time empowered, because of the office that he or she held, to arrest the person, and

before starting the questioning the investigating official did not caution the person that the person does not have to say or do anything but that anything the person does say or do may be used in evidence.
For the purposes of section 138(1)(a) , evidence of a statement made or an act done by a person during questioning is taken to have been obtained improperly if:
the questioning was conducted by an investigating official who did not have the power to arrest the person, and
the statement was made, or the act was done, after the investigating official formed a belief that there was sufficient evidence to establish that the person has committed an offence, and

the investigating official did not, before the statement was made or the act was done, caution the person that the person does not have to say or do anything but that anything the person does say or do may be used in evidence.
[subs (2) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[65], effective 1 January 2009]

The caution must be given in, or translated into, a language in which the person is able to communicate with reasonable fluency, but need not be given in writing unless the person cannot hear adequately.
Subsections (1) , (2) and (3) do not apply so far as any Australian law requires the person to answer questions put by, or do things required by, the investigating official.
A reference in subsection (1) to a person who is under arrest includes a reference to a person who is in the company of an investigating official for the purpose of being questioned, if:
the official believes that there is sufficient evidence to establish that the person has committed an offence that is to be the subject of the questioning, or
the official would not allow the person to leave if the person wished to do so, or
the official has given the person reasonable grounds for believing that the person would not be allowed to leave if he or she wished to do so.

the official is performing functions in relation to persons or goods entering or leaving Australia and the official does not believe the person has committed an offence against a law of the Commonwealth, or
the official is exercising a power under an Australian law to detain and search the person or to require the person to provide information or to answer questions.
See Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 10 of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .
